episode.title: Village of Belle Terre v. Boraas

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in Number 73-191, Village of Belle Terre against Boraas and others.
Mr. Gegan.

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
I appear for the Village of Belle Terre and the named individual defendants in this action on an appeal from a judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
That judgment held unconstitutional, a portion of the zoning law of the village.
The portion that it held unconstitutional provided that; number one, the village has a one-family zone.

The Court did not dispute that, but families defined in terms of two -- of a family-related by blood, adoption or marriage or an unrelated individuals living in a household, but are not in excess of two.
The Village of Belle Terre --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So, a household then could consist either of a group of people not limited in number related by blood, adoption or marriage or of two people not related by blood, adoption or marriage.

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: According to the ordinance, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: So, the three spinsters could not live together?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: According to this ordinance, that is just so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But two homosexuals could?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
The Village of Belle Terre is a small community of 700 people approximately on the north shore of Long Island in Suffolk County.
The plaintiffs, the Dickmans own a house within the village and rented it to six students of the State University at Stony Brook.
The village threatened to enforce its ordinance with attendant criminal penalties against these individuals and they commenced the action in the Federal District Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the students were all unrelated to each other by blood or marriage, were they not?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Yes, they were, that was in their complaint, so alleged, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And they were -- some were males, some were females, correct?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Apparently, one was a female, Your Honor, yes.
Pending this appeal, I was informed that these students had left and so stated in my brief.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They were all graduate students, were they not?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Not all of them, Your Honor.
Some of them were.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But they left because they completed their (Voice Overlap)?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: We have no knowledge of why they left, Your Honor.
I am updated by counsel for the plaintiffs, as they state in their supplemental brief that they have been replaced by six more unrelated adults.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Oh!

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: So, we are now back in that position.
I would like in the beginning to proceed from the general --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are these new tenants parties to the case or not?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: They are not parties to the case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It is not a class action?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: It is not a class action, Your Honor.
It was an individual action.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well then, does it make any difference whether the house is occupied by these people or by no one at all?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: I think insofar as the case could be thought to be moot this --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: By the same --?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: The Dickmans have continued to be plaintiffs throughout and have never withdrawn or left.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They aren't (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: They are the owners of the house and are co-plaintiffs and their interests have been continuous and now of course, they've been revived by the new group of unrelated persons.
In discussing the constitutionality of the law, I would like to proceed, if I may from the general to the particular.

I would begin by stating what I would like to think of as a starting point for analysis of the issues here that laid down in Euclid v. Ambler, that a state may legitimately have a one-family zone as sep -- community, may legitimately have a one-family zone as distinguished from a two-family detached, as distinguished from apartments, commercial, light industrial and so on down the line.

If that is true, and if the one-family zone which this town has a right to enact, if the one-family zone is to have any meaning, you have the problem of an unlimited number of persons assembling under the roof in the one-family house.
I suppose the village has a couple of alternatives.
It could just forget about its one-family zone and have no limit on the number of people of any type that could live in a building.
I don't think it's required to throw out its one-family zoning.
Or as plaintiffs suggest in their brief, they could have an across the broad limit, a maximum number of people can live in the house according to the number of bedrooms or some other formula.
Across the board!
The consequences of this suggestion would be to penalize larger families, families with children for example in excess of the number of bedrooms in the house.
Whether it would be constitutional for a village to do this, I don't even discuss. Certainly, a village as at liberty not to make that policy judgment.
At this point, I think we come to the crux issues in the case.
Are there any circumstances in which the village can treat the family because of what it is, because of the value it has for our society, can it treat the family different from the unrelated group.

And the third alternative is the one the village adapted here, to have a numerical limitation on the number of unrelated people, but no numerical limitation on families counting on the normal expectancy that families tend to remain within a certain range, whereas there is no such expectancy or predictable size of group in the case of unrelated individuals.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The whole village zoned as one-family?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Yes, it was, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought --

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: And I -- on that point, the plaintiffs make something of that in that their argument is that if Belle Terre can do it, so can everybody else and unrelated groups might find themselves eventually deprived of convenient and fitting places to live.
Addressing myself just to that question, Your Honor, I first wish to reemphasize, there were two issues.
One, is the village appropriately zoned for what it is.
Second, what body has the right to make the zoning decision?
This is the point that the plaintiffs challenge on this branch of the case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does this village have a legal right to grant variations or exceptions from their zoning for people?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They have not?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, there is no administrative machinery.
It is a fixed zone, no variance.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The village of Belle Terre depends for its zoning authority on the grant from the town of Brookfield, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Well, it derives it directly from State Law under the New York State Village Law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Town -- the town of Brookfield then has no control over what zoning does the --

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Well, the way it works, Your Honor is that the town has zoning power, but if the village incorporates within the geographic area of a town, it then acquires zoning power over its area.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Without reference to the town?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Without reference to the town, but to the extent that the village is not an incorporated village, the town's zoning is applicable.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You say it's a single family, are there no commercial retail store areas, that sort of thing.

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: No, not within these villages.
It's just single-family houses, residential.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What's the population of Belle Terre?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: 700 people, Your Honor and approximately 220 homes.

The consequences of the plaintiffs' argument on this branch of the case apparently would be and I can’t see anyway around it that they would say, it's unconstitutional to have a governmental entity endowed with zoning power unless that governmental body itself could accommodate the full range of zoning uses.
This -- just the argument is that since Belle Terre consists solely of one-family residences.
It shouldn't be able to zone unless it can accommodate other users.
This is a -- an astonishing proposition that would render innumerable zoning ordinances all across the country unconstitutional.
It would negate the value of local economy which this Court so recently emphasized in the San Antonio School District case.

Why this astonishing conclusion is pressed on this Court apparently is that the plaintiff's belief that if Belle Terre is allowed to have its one family zone, then other communities will zone them out.
Mind you, the argument is not that this is the present situation.
On the contrary, Judge Dooling made his finding of fact down below, that Belle Terre is a tiny unit within a large area of permissibly zoned area.

He made the finding that the town of Brook Haven within which the university is and within which the village is, that the town of Brook Haven, even its highest zoning district would accommodate the residential use engaged in by the plaintiff students.
So the argument is not that under the present existing circumstances, the students have been deprived of a meaningful and appropriate place to reside.
The argument is that it might become so in the future.
The Second Circuit Court of Appeals accepted this argument.
I think this turns upside down, the presumption of constitutionality.
We have a tradition that if any state of facts might be conceived, that would make the operation of a law reasonable then the law is valid.

The Court of Appeals reversed this upside down that if any state of facts might be conceived in future by which the operation of a law become unreasonable, then the law must be held valid, void, presently.

Now of course, the Village of Belle Terre excludes two-family houses, but no one is in a panic thinking that Havens, if Belle Terre excludes two-family houses, there'll be no place for two-family houses.
The plaintiff group consisting of unrelated people is not the kind of suspect minority which this Court contemplated in the Old Caroline Products case, Footnote 4.
They are numerous.
They are articulate.
They are educated.
They are mobile in the sense that members of this group become members of families and back and forth.
So, they are the very opposite of the kind of helpless minority in whose behalf, strict or special judicial scrutiny is invoked.
The plaintiffs on -- at a couple of points in their brief try to impute to the village some sort of judgment that individuals living in group are per se socially undesirable.
I suppose, they are trying to come close to the Marino case recently decided by this Court which said that the State has no legitimate interest in punishing politically unpopular groups.
Well of course, that would be the antithesis of a bill of attainder and no one would assert that as a constitutionally permissible purpose.

But this kind of division that they try to impute to the village, that we in the village, the families are the good guys and groups are somehow the bad guys, the social undesirables that are excluded, that are out.
This distorts totally the kind of fine-tuned judgments that are made in zoning.
If you have a zone for one-family residential community, that does not express a judgment that people living in two-family houses are undesirables.
It excludes a monastery, 50 monks living in it.
There's no judgment that the 50 monks are undesirables.
It's a rather fine-tuned judgment that certain users are more appropriately put off into one zone.
The plaintiffs use the epithet separate but equal.
Well an epithet has an odium connected with it because of its legal history.
But logically, the concept separate but equal, I must admit, is the concept of zoning.

I think in this case that of all of the opinions written below, the most acute statement was that of Judge Dooling in the District Court, in the jurisdictional statement, page 88, in which he said, "The essence of zoning is that its selection is not regarded as invidiously discriminatory against users not selected.
Zoning presupposes that convenient and fitting locations can be found for every legitimate land use so that no pursuit of any use is denied of disparaged."
Now, you can call that separate, but equal if you will, but that's what it is.
The exclusion of one land use from Zone X is not the kind of invidious judgment that excluding unrelated groups from food stamp programs is.
To exclude unrelated groups from food stamp programs does not put any bread and nourishment in the stomachs of families.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well here, you don't have an exclusion of unrelated groups, at least as I understand the ordinance.
You have a limitation on their number as to two where you don't have the same limitation on the number in the family, that the town hasn't excluded unrelated groups.

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: That's true, Your Honor.
I would say in candor, however that my basic principle rests to a certain degree on the concept of density.

I think density certainly explains the general concept of why a village would want to put in numerical limit on the number of unrelated people while leaving traditional families without a numerical limit.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, just to suggest one, six completely independent autonomous adults are more likely to have more automobiles and use up more parking space than one family unit with two children, are they not?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Among other, definitely one, Your Honor. One of the rational perceived grounds upon which this distinction would be made.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't this one of the basis on which the zoning ordinances will require X number of square feet parking space for every X number of living space in an apartment building so that persons living nearby in the apartment are not going to be having their space on the street taken up by the overflow from the apartment building.

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: I think that is exactly so Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So, that'd be true in a lesser degree right here, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Yes.
I do feel --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But your --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: But the record here doesn't show that is the reason, does it?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: One of the problems --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: As I understand it, when it went back for findings, nothing was added to the record?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: We feel Your Honor, this way.

The United States Court of Appeals said that the village has not proved the existence of problems whether it'd be problems of transiency and community stability, whether it be problems of density, or whether it be problems in the ability of families to compete for the rental of a house against six wage earners.
These were the various reasons the village endorsed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Doesn't McGowan or up to now, hasn't McGowan against Maryland said that an Appellate Court may conjure up any reason that supports the result?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and I don't even go that far, but I do stand here strongly objecting to the notion of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals that the village somehow had to prove, as if it were an adjudicative fact to be proved by the preponderance of the evidence, the facts underlying -- the legislative facts underlying its ordinance.

To the contrary, we insisted there and we ins -- we went back to the District Court and refused to put in any further facts and we insist here that so long as the state of facts which the village apprehends is rationally arguable, which reasonable men could perceive that if we don't have this ordinance, certain problems will develop, that that is sufficient to justify the constitutionality of the ordinance.
We don't even ask the Court to exercise sua sponte imagination to impute purposes to the village.
The village comes before you tendering legitimate, reasonable public purposes which underlie the statute.
The fact that the number of unrelated persons can't exceed two might be thought harsh if density were the only rationale underlying this ordinance.
That is why the village has other rational basis underlying this ordinance.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean, you might have difficulty of -- the requirement in addition to what you now have is that in every house must be a minimum of five acres?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It might be in trouble with that?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: I would certainly feel uncomfortable with it and I don't want to carry that burden.
So, to justify --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you have one-acre limitation?

turn.speaker: bernard_e_gegan
turn.label: Mr. Bernard E. Gegan
turn.text: One acre.
Yes it is, Your Honor.
To justify the number of two as applied to groups of unrelated individuals, it seems obvious to us that we have an economic problem staring us in the face.

We are 15 minutes away as the affidavit show from Stony Brook University, a large unit of a state university and a particular number and I asked you Your Honors to notice it, is some 12,000 odd students.
They have more faculty than we have residents.

So, there is potentially tremendous supply of unrelated individuals who would be ready to form groups were this ordinance not existing and we argue that the legitimate interest in rental parity and equity between a family which has one wage earner or at most two wage earners would be priced out of the rental market if --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll resume at that point at ten o’clock in the morning, gentleman.
